intro: Gilia clivorum, commonly known as the Sierra gilia, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its showy, colorful flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows in rocky habitats, such as cliffs and slopes, and thrives in full sun. It has hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine pubescence. Gilia clivorum is known for its ability to attract pollinators like bees and butterflies due to its bright, tubular flowers.
